# Fact-Finding and Cyber Attribution

## NICHOLAS TSAGOURIAS AND FIONA MIDDLETON

### 15.1 INTRODUCTION

As our societies become increasingly reliant on cyberspace, they also become vulnerable to cyberattacks¹ committed by States or non-State actors either independently or in collaboration with each other. States and non-State actors exploit this complex environment and the anonymity, speed, and interconnectivity it affords to cause harm. Attribution is important in such a context because it concerns the process of assigning a cyberattack to its source, which is a prerequisite for any remedial action and for establishing responsibility.

In international law, attribution refers to the legal process of assigning an act or omission to a State (or another subject of international law), and it is one of the constitutive elements of the law of State responsibility. A State can incur responsibility only if a wrongful act or omission is attributed to it according to the criteria established in the law of State responsibility. A cyberattack can thus be attributed to a State according to the criteria contained in Articles 4–11 of the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (2001) and engage its responsibility if it constitutes a breach of one of its obligations.²

That said, attribution, in general, and cyber attribution, in particular, have also a factual dimension. The factual dimension of cyber attribution refers to the attribution of a cyberattack to its source based on technical facts. This requires technical investigations conducted mainly by cyber forensics experts.³

The two processes of attribution (legal and factual/technical) cannot be clearly decoupled because legal attribution is fact-dependent. To explain, facts need to be discovered and assessed according to the legal criteria of attribution in order to assign a particular cyberattack to a State for legal purposes.

It is for this reason that attribution claims are often accompanied by reports containing supporting evidence. These reports are compiled by the State making the attribution claim, often assisted by private cybersecurity companies.⁴ However, in most cases these reports are quite thin on evidence and do not always explain how facts were assessed.⁵ Consequently, accused States, and sometimes third States, contest the attribution claims by disputing the facts and the supporting evidence.

By contesting the facts, States not only challenge implicitly or explicitly the attribution claim, but they also dispute the legal claim that can be drawn from attribution, for example, a legal claim that international law has been breached and responsibility is incurred. This is because legal inferences and valuations are drawn from facts or, to put it differently, because facts are law-dispositive.

When a dispute arises, States have an obligation to settle it peacefully.¹⁸ This obligation is fundamental because it is indispensable for maintaining international peace and security.¹⁹ States can, to that effect, employ a variety of dispute settlement mechanisms, with fact-finding being one such mechanism in and of itself or as part of another dispute settlement mechanism.²⁰

# 15.2 FACT-FINDING AND INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE SETTLEMENT

Fact-finding as a method of dispute settlement has been recognised in the 1899 Hague Convention for the Pacific Settlement of International Disputes and is also mentioned in Article 33 of the UN Charter.[21] Its importance for the peaceful settlement of disputes and for maintaining international peace was also stressed by the UN General Assembly (UNGA) in several Resolutions.[22]

The primary aim of fact-finding is to 'elucidate' facts underlying a dispute by locating, identifying, verifying, corroborating, and analysing them.[23] The assumption is that by resolving factual controversies, it is not only the factual

dispute that will be settled, but also that legal disputes linked to the facts will be prevented, accommodated, or settled.

Although fact-finding was envisaged as an objective and impartial mechanism of ascertaining facts, it evolved over the years to address a range of different situations and issues.²⁴ For example, fact-finding missions have been endowed with monitoring, alerting, and recommendatory tasks. They have also exercised adjudicative functions by identifying violations of international law or determining the applicability of specific legal rules,²⁵ and in this way, fact-finding contributed directly or indirectly to accountability at the individual or State level.²⁶ This meant that the nature of fact-finding changed from investigating facts to acquiring a juridical dimension either directly or indirectly because facts cannot be disentangled easily from law.²⁷ As a result of such changes, fact-finding has sometimes exacerbated existing disputes or triggered additional disputes about fact-finding itself.²⁸

In addition to international organisations, NGOs have also formed FFMs in relation to specific incidents and, more generally, to collect evidence.⁵⁵ An example is the Independent Civil Society Fact-Finding Mission in Libya which was created by the Arab Organisation for Human Rights in cooperation with the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights. The objective of this fact-finding mission was to investigate widespread violations of international law in Libya.⁵⁶

What all this shows is that in addition to States, a vast array of organisations – intergovernmental, nongovernmental, general, specialised – have created and deployed FFMs. Their power to do so is either expressed or implied, and such fact-finding missions are either *ad hoc* creations or permanent features of the organisation.

## 15.2.2 Fact-Finding Structure and Methodology

A FFM’s structure and methodology includes, among others, matters concerning membership, mandates, resources, and working methods; the time-scale and territorial scope of the investigations; the type of evidence that will be used and how it will be gathered, handled, and assessed; the applicable standard of proof; and reporting and communication mechanisms. It may also include information about the applicable international law framework.⁵⁷

These matters are key for the proper functioning of the FFM, for the credibility, reliability, objectivity, and legitimacy of its process and findings, and eventually for the success of the FFM.⁵⁸ How they are dealt with depends on the FFM’s mandate, goals, and institutional basis; the wishes of the parties; and international law as the overarching regulatory tool – but what is important to stress is that fact-finding missions should have clear and transparent provisions to that effect.

# 15.3 CURRENT CHALLENGES TO FACT-FINDING AS DISPUTE SETTLEMENT MECHANISM

## 15.3.1 State Consent

The consent of the States involved in the dispute is important for the deployment of FFMs, their legitimacy, and the effective performance of their tasks. However, international organisations have often departed from this principle by relying on their competence to establish such an FFM as provided in their constitutive treaties to which States consented.⁵⁹

Such an approach is formally correct but causes two main difficulties. The first concerns the legal basis upon which the FFM can perform its tasks within the disputing States. As we saw, international organisations may recommend an FFM in which case the consent of the States involved in the dispute is critical for its deployment. However, even if an international organisation has been granted the power to establish an FFM, its deployment on the territory of a particular State, or its investigations without State consent, may amount to a violation of that State's sovereignty or an unlawful intervention.⁶⁰ Article 2(7) of the UN Charter, for example, prohibits UN intervention in the domestic jurisdiction of its member States, except for Chapter VII enforcement action. Fact-finding is not, however, enforcement action, even if it is established under Chapter VII. Even if one could say that States have granted a priori consent by becoming members of an international organisation, and even if the organisation can instruct States to accept the deployment of an FFM, if States oppose its actual deployment, the only option is to enforce the deployment of the FFM, something that may require military support.

This leads to the second difficulty which relates to the effectiveness of fact-finding. If States give their consent, the FFM will be able to access and gather information,⁶¹ which will make its work and findings more credible and reliable. In contrast, if States are forced to admit an FFM, they may obstruct its work or fail to co-operate fully. If States refuse to admit an FFM or refuse access to certain sources, an FFM may be forced to gather evidence from secondary or external sources, which may impact the reliability and credibility

# 15.3.2 Fact-Finding Structure and Methodology

As said before, having a clear and transparent structure and methodology is important, but existing practice indicates that FFMs are often deficient in this regard. For example, mandates or working methods are not always stated in clear or explicit terms.[62] Membership is often political or, at least, politicised,[63] and, more critically, the expertise or the capacity of members to handle complex facts is often questioned.

Furthermore, FFMs do not always state which standard of proof they apply when assessing evidence, and different commissions apply different standards. They include, inter alia, standards of reasonable suspicion, reasonable grounds, sufficient credible and reliable information, and sufficiently substantiated and overwhelming evidence.[64] Even if variation is to be expected given that each FFM is an independent institution having its own mandate, stating what is the applicable standard and applying it consistently is critical for the reliability and credibility of the fact-finding process and determinations, particularly if they are used for accountability purposes. ## 15.4 CYBER ATTRIBUTION AND FACT-FINDING

Following a short presentation of fact-finding, this section discusses the contours of fact-finding in the context of cyber attribution. More specifically, it considers what types of facts are pertinent for cyber attribution purposes and the methodology a cyber attribution FFM should apply to ascertain the facts. It then considers how such an FFM can be established, and, in this respect, it also assesses the proposed cyber attribution mechanisms.

## 15.4.1 Cyber Facts and Cyber Fact-Finding Methodology

In relation to cyber attribution, the notion of facts differs in certain respects from the types of facts that FFMs usually ascertain. FFMs usually ascertain physical facts by relying on physical, observable evidence, or testimonies⁷¹ which they retrieve from on-site visits, investigations, and interviews with people.

Although facts ascertained through such evidence and methods are also relevant to cyber attribution in order, for example, to determine the physical location of cyberattacks or their effects, the bulk of cyber facts are technical. They are also ascertained on the basis of technical evidence following technical (forensic) investigations.

Technical evidence consists of artefacts drawn from the tools, techniques, and procedures used for the cyberattack.⁷² It includes, among others, command-and-control servers, IP addresses, websites, activity logs, time stamps, malware and their design, names, and pseudonyms, software programmes, e-mails, instructions, language strings, documents, and so on.⁷³ Technical evidence can be collected through technical investigations from different points of the cyberattack cycle: preparation, reconnaissance, exploitation, execution, and post-execution phase.⁷⁴

All this indicates that fact-finding for cyber attribution purposes is a more holistic process. It has a strong technical component in that the facts and methods according to which facts are located, retrieved, ascertained, and assessed are primarily technical, but other non-technical facts should also be factored in.

Inevitably, this poses many challenges to fact-finding. A primary challenge is jurisdictional and refers to the ability and competence of the FFM to access evidence. Although, arguably, using cyber means and methods facilitates investigations — because it extends their reach, makes access to cyber evidence easier by not requiring physical presence, and surpasses impediments caused by geography, war, or unrest — legal jurisdictional impediments still exist. Investigations, even remote ones, require direct access to networks, and, therefore, the consent of the State or party that owns the network is needed, but access may be denied or restricted. Moreover, investigations may need to take place outside the jurisdiction of the disputing States because of the interconnected nature of cyber infrastructure and the ability of threat actors to operate from within different jurisdictions. If consent is denied, withdrawn, or restricted, fact-finding (on-site or remotely conducted) will be hindered. If the FFM carries out investigations without State consent, it may face accusations of having violated international law. If, in the absence of a direct access, it relies on external and secondary sources, the credibility, reliability, and legitimacy of its findings may be contested.

Besides jurisdictional limitations, another challenge concerns the diagnostic capacity of the FFM. For example, the FFM will need to have the appropriate technical resources, know-how, and skills in order to be able to gather and assess technical evidence. If such resources are not available or are limited, the FFM will not be able to perform these tasks efficiently or with the required degree of confidence. The immediate question is whether, in order to overcome this challenge, fact-finding can be delegated to expert third parties such as private security companies. If technical fact-finding is delegated to third parties, questions about the neutrality and impartiality of fact-finding may be raised, alongside questions about the credibility and reliability of the findings because of the inability of the FFM to scrutinise the determinations of third parties due to lack of resources, knowledge, and expertise.

This leads to another challenge, which concerns the applicable methodology. FFMs have their own rules, standards, and methods of identifying, analysing, establishing, ascertaining, probing, and using facts. The

As we also said, FFMs do not apply any uniform standard, which raises questions about the applicable standard of proof. Even more critically, as indicated above, there are many difficulties in collecting and tracing cyber evidence which are compounded by the fact that an FFM cannot demand the production of evidence or use judicial or police mechanisms to obtain evidence unless this is provided in their constitutive document. What value should be placed then on secondary evidence to corroborate facts if primary evidence is hard to obtain?

In addition, the timescale within which the FFM can deliver its report is also important. Cyber fact-finding may take longer because of its complexity, the technical resources required due to the pace of developments in this area, and the jurisdictional hurdles that must be overcome. A thorough but longer investigation may increase the reliability and credibility of fact-finding, but may undermine its functions in cases where a swift action is needed. A faster fact-finding process may be more useful but less reliable. If a fact-finding mission's report is issued after action has been taken, it may reignite and escalate the dispute.

# 15.4.2.1 Intergovernmental Cyber Attribution Agency

The creation of an intergovernmental cyber attribution agency was proposed by the Atlantic Council. More specifically, it proposed the establishment of a Multilateral Cyber Adjudication and Attribution Council (MCAAC) with mixed (public and private) membership.^[83]^

The underlying idea is that an intergovernmental cyber attribution agency grounded on State consent and operating on the basis of agreed standards and processes will overcome States’ reservations and legitimise its standing, operation, and findings. Whether an international intergovernmental attribution agency is viable at this moment in time is doubtful.

First, States treat cyber attribution as a sovereign prerogative and have repeatedly said that they have no obligation to disclose evidence.^[84]^

Its membership will most likely be limited due to States' diverse cyber capabilities and the rivalry that currently characterises their relations. Technologically developed States or cyber powers, in general, may chose to remain outside such an agency because of the limited benefits they will receive. This immediately raises questions about the agency's resources and its mandate. If the agency's resources are inadequate, will its mandate be limited and, in this case, what will be its added value? If important cyber powers are not members, will its findings be reliable and credible? Also, what will be its leverage to conduct investigations into third States, or States that have isolated their cyberspace? If technologically developed States do participate, would that create an imbalance and invite accusations of bias regarding its findings? If a State is frequently accused of cyberattacks, is there any benefit in participating in such an agency?

An intergovernmental cyber attribution agency will also face certain methodological challenges, such as regarding the criteria according to which attribution incidents will be investigated and the type of attribution it will perform, for example, technical and/or legal. These issues need to be determined in advance, but it is doubtful whether that will be possible due to the permanent and general competence of such an agency, the dynamic nature of cyber incidents, the difficulty in disentangling law from facts, and the inherent power of institutions to interpret and determine their mandate in view of new circumstances.

Another critical question is who will conduct the fact-finding. If fact-finding is to be performed by State officials, the process may be politicised. If it is to be performed by the agency's staff, recruited because of their qualifications and professional experience, the agency will need to build its own fact-finding

capabilities and expertise, but the immediate question is who is going to provide the resources, know-how, and training. As we said, States may be reluctant to share their technical attribution tools and knowledge, and, in general, they may not be ready to support and fund the development of attribution expertise by such an agency which can then compete with them. If investigations or capacity-building is delegated to third parties, such as the private sector, instead, it may affect the legitimacy, impartiality, and reliability of an agency, as mentioned previously.

Other methodological challenges include the applicable standard of proof; the legal framework governing the agency's investigations such as human rights law or intellectual property law; the availability of review mechanisms; and the manner in which and to whom findings will be communicated, for example, whether they will be made public or remain confidential.

How an agency will make decisions presents another challenge. Consensus-based decisions may be more acceptable, but trying to build consensus may impact the ability of the agency to make quick decisions, or may affect the quality and transparency of its decisions. If decisions are majority-based, division and accusations may follow.

Ensuring the accountability of such an agency is another challenge. Its findings may be relied upon by States to act, which raises the question of whether the agency can be held responsible for incorrect determinations, or for assisting in the commission of unlawful acts. If a State, for instance, relies on the agency's findings to take countermeasures against another State which contends that the countermeasures were unlawful because the attribution was mistaken, can the agency be held responsible for incorrect findings, or for aiding in the commission of wrongful acts? If the matter is brought before a court or an arbitration tribunal, what value should be placed on the findings of such an agency? For example, should that court or tribunal treat them as mitigating circumstances when considering damages?

There is also the fundamental question of the status of the agency. If it is consultative, its contribution to dispute settlement may be negligible because States may employ other mechanisms or use their own judgment to settle their cyber attribution disputes. However, even in this case, there is still a danger of aggravating an existing dispute because its findings, even if non-binding, may be used by States to validate or disprove attribution claims, thus providing no closure to the dispute. If its status is adjudicatory and its findings are binding

## 15.4.2.2 A Private Cyber Attribution Agency

A proposal for the creation of a private cyber attribution agency was put forward by RAND. More specifically, it proposed the creation of a Global Cyber Attribution Consortium whose role would be to attribute major cyberattacks with a high degree of confidence and release the evidence and its findings to the public.⁸⁹

According to the proposal, the agency's membership will be multi-stakeholder, consisting of technical, legal, and policy experts from academia, research organisations, and cybersecurity and information technology companies, but State representatives will be excluded. The agency will also follow a standardised methodology regarding the collection of evidence, assessment, standard of proof, review, notification, and publication of findings.

It is claimed that the private character of such an agency will remove suspicions of politicisation, and its findings will contribute to dispute settlement by making attribution neutral, credible, and reliable. According to RAND, the consortium can only derive its legitimacy over time from 'the reputation and credibility gained from the technical expertise of its diverse global membership and its commitment to objectivity and transparency in its attribution findings'.⁹⁰

Although the proposal tries to circumvent State reluctance or suspicion towards an intergovernmental attribution agency, it is reasonable to ask whether it is appropriate and viable to exclude States to the extent that attribution determinations, even if they are exclusively factual, may affect State interests and decisions or have legal consequences, for example, the imposition of sanctions.⁹¹ Questions may also be asked about the competence and ability of such an agency to conduct investigations when States involved

in a dispute refuse to co-operate. The private character of such an agency does not ensure that States will co-operate or disclose information. Furthermore, depending on how information is gathered, handled, assessed, and communicated by such an agency, the credibility and reliability of its findings can be challenged for lack of evidence or faulty methodology.

There are several other challenges facing a private attribution agency. First, whereas the participation of private security companies can boost the technical capabilities of the agency, how they will be selected is critical for the credibility of the agency. Secondly, these companies will continue to operate independently and often compete with the agency, which will raise questions about their commitment to the work of the agency. Third, in a competitive cybersecurity market, other private cybersecurity companies may challenge the agency's findings, which can create confusion and lower the level of confidence in the agency. Fourth, the private sector is not equally developed in all States, and States have different views about its role in cyber governance, which may create suspicion or even opposition to the involvement of the private sector.

Another challenge concerns the accountability of this agency for the same reasons mentioned above, but with an additional twist. If the agency does not operate under international law, it will not be subject to international law's accountability mechanisms. This immediately raises the question of whether national accountability mechanisms will be used against the agency or its individual members. If that is to happen, it will have a chilling effect on the agency and create confusion and uncertainty.

Finally, the private character of such an agency may pose a systemic challenge to international law because it will antagonise or even undermine States which, as we said, want to preserve their power to perform attribution and settle their disputes as they see fit. Such an agency may also undermine States' control over the international law process of rule creation, application, and interpretation if it is involved, explicitly or implicitly, in the interpretation or application of international law or in laying down new standards. In addition, another systemic challenge should be mentioned. The proliferation of attribution mechanisms may cause more confusion and conflict and aggravate disputes further instead of settling them.

All this means that such an agency's claim to neutrality, reliability, and legality may not be fully supported.

## 15.5 Moving forward: an ffm for cyber attribution?

In the preceding sections, we identified several institutional, structural, and methodological challenges that affect cyber attribution fact-finding. That said,

Nicholas Tsagourias and Fiona Middleton

cyber attribution disputes exist and, if not settled, may aggravate or exacerbate the underlying political and legal disputes. Thus, the question of how to establish the facts underlying a cyber attribution claim cannot go away. For this reason, in this section we will present the key features and attributes of a cyber attribution FFM which, in our opinion, could address many of the aforementioned challenges.

In the first place, such an FFM should be created by States voluntarily and on an ad hoc basis in relation to a particular cyber attribution dispute.92 States' involvement in its creation and design will demonstrate their determination to settle the attribution dispute. It will also elicit their cooperation and compliance since the FFM will be entangled with the particular interests and expectations of the disputing States. Finally, it will contribute to the credibility, legitimacy, and effectiveness of the FFM. This does not contradict what we said previously, namely that States view cyber attribution as their sovereign prerogative and claim that they have no obligation to disclose evidence, or that they use attribution for strategic purposes. These remain true, but they are more pertinent in relation to fact-finding performed by permanent international institutions over which disputing States have little control, or in relation to demands to publicly disclose information. However, if States determine that settling a cyber attribution dispute is more important than letting the dispute linger or aggravate, and that settling it through an FFM is appropriate, effective, and serves their interests, they may go ahead to create such an FFM and co-operate with it. As a matter of fact, this is not against their sovereignty but confirmation of their sovereignty.

From a broader perspective, this approach to FFMs accords with the fact that States are the primary creators and designers of dispute settlement mechanisms, and that fact-finding was originally envisaged as a bilateral mechanism of dispute settlement and not as an institutional one.

Since being created by States, the FFM should be treaty-based. States will thus be able to specify in its constitutive instrument its composition, mandate, and methodology.

The composition of the FFM should be determined by the States concerned, depending on the nature and mandate of the FFM. Members can be State officials, staff borrowed from international organisations, individuals drawn from the private sector, or NGOs. Their expertise can also cover different fields, for example, technology and/or law. We are thus not prescriptive as existing proposals are, and we do not place value on a certain type of membership, but believe that membership should reflect the interests and needs of the States which establish the FFM.

92 UNGA, 'Declaration on fact-finding', paras 6 and 21.

https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Fact-Finding and Cyber Attribution

Insofar as its mandate is concerned, it should again be determined by States. In the first place, the constitutive instrument should specify the subject matter of the investigation. It should specify, for example, which incident(s) will be investigated and under what circumstances other related incidents will be investigated. It should also specify what type of facts it will gather and assess, and whether the FFM will perform only technical and/or legal attribution. This is important because it has implications for the methodology the FFM will follow. In addition to the above, the FFM's constitutive instrument should specify the location of the investigations, for example, which and whose networks it will investigate, and under what circumstances it will extend its investigations to connected networks. It should also specify the timeframe of investigations; the processes and conditions of gathering, storing, handling, or sharing evidence; the process according to which evidence will be assessed; and the means of establishing their authenticity and reliability.

Furthermore, the constitutive instrument should specify the applicable standard of proof depending on the type of attribution it will perform, and whether the FFM will have an adjudicatory or consultative function. It should also state how and by whom its findings will be reviewed.

There are several other issues that the FFM's constitutive instrument should specify. It should specify the terms and words used in the mandate, such as attribution, networks, and non-State actors. It should specify the guiding principles of the FFM, for example, its adherence to the principles of transparency, fairness, neutrality, and accountability. It should specify the law that will apply to the FFM and its investigations, for example, whether the investigations will be conducted according to international law.

Regarding the decision-making process, the constitutive instrument should state whether decisions will be consensual or majority-based. It should also explain the reporting and communication process, including whether the findings will remain private and confidential, or made public, and whether, in the latter case, evidence will be made public. This is important because it will have implications on the applicable methodology.

The constitutive instrument should make provisions for a continuous supply of financial,[93] technical, or any other resources required for the performance of the FFM's duties.

https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press

Finally, the constitutive instrument should establish internal and/or external accountability mechanisms.

We believe that, if States create a cyber attribution FFM which addresses all these issues with the requisite care, the FFM will be able to operate smoothly and efficiently and establish the facts underpinning cyber attribution disputes in a credible and reliable manner. It can thus contribute to dispute resolution without becoming itself the subject of a dispute.

### 15.6 conclusion

This chapter has considered the role of fact-finding as a mechanism for settling cyber attribution disputes. In this respect, it discussed its merits but also identified several challenges it is facing relating to its legal basis, institutional nature, structure, and methodology. The chapter then went on to present certain key features a cyber attribution FFM should exhibit, which will enable it, in the view of the authors, to perform its fact-finding tasks effectively. In our opinion, if fact-finding is calibrated appropriately, it can contribute to the peaceful settlement of cyber attribution disputes.

### 15.1 INTRODUCTION
As our societies become increasingly reliant on cyberspace, they also become vulnerable to cyberattacks¹ committed by States or non-State actors either independently or in collaboration with each other. States and non-State actors exploit this complex environment and the anonymity, speed, and interconnectivity it affords to cause harm. Attribution is important in such a context because it concerns the process of assigning a cyberattack to its source, which is a prerequisite for any remedial action and for establishing responsibility.
In international law, attribution refers to the legal process of assigning an act or omission to a State (or another subject of international law), and it is one of the constitutive elements of the law of State responsibility. A State can incur responsibility only if a wrongful act or omission is attributed to it according to the criteria established in the law of State responsibility. A cyberattack can thus be attributed to a State according to the criteria contained in Articles 4–11 of the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (2001) and engage its responsibility if it constitutes a breach of one of its obligations.²
That said, attribution, in general, and cyber attribution, in particular, have also a factual dimension. The factual dimension of cyber attribution refers to the attribution of a cyberattack to its source based on technical facts. This requires technical investigations conducted mainly by cyber forensics experts.³

The chapter attempts to answer this question by first discussing in Section 15.2 the role of fact-finding in international dispute settlement as well as its legal, institutional, structural, and methodological modalities. In Section 15.3, the chapter will identify several challenges fact-finding is currently facing. These two sections provide the background for the discussion that will follow in Section 15.4 of fact-finding for purposes of cyber attribution. # 15.2 FACT-FINDING AND INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE SETTLEMENT
Fact-finding as a method of dispute settlement has been recognised in the 1899 Hague Convention for the Pacific Settlement of International Disputes and is also mentioned in Article 33 of the UN Charter.[21] Its importance for the peaceful settlement of disputes and for maintaining international peace was also stressed by the UN General Assembly (UNGA) in several Resolutions.[22]
The primary aim of fact-finding is to 'elucidate' facts underlying a dispute by locating, identifying, verifying, corroborating, and analysing them.[23] The assumption is that by resolving factual controversies, it is not only the factual

Although fact-finding was envisaged as an objective and impartial mechanism of ascertaining facts, it evolved over the years to address a range of different situations and issues.²⁴ For example, fact-finding missions have been endowed with monitoring, alerting, and recommendatory tasks. They have also exercised adjudicative functions by identifying violations of international law or determining the applicability of specific legal rules,²⁵ and in this way, fact-finding contributed directly or indirectly to accountability at the individual or State level.²⁶ This meant that the nature of fact-finding changed from investigating facts to acquiring a juridical dimension either directly or indirectly because facts cannot be disentangled easily from law.²⁷ As a result of such changes, fact-finding has sometimes exacerbated existing disputes or triggered additional disputes about fact-finding itself.²⁸

## 15.2.2 Fact-Finding Structure and Methodology
A FFM’s structure and methodology includes, among others, matters concerning membership, mandates, resources, and working methods; the time-scale and territorial scope of the investigations; the type of evidence that will be used and how it will be gathered, handled, and assessed; the applicable standard of proof; and reporting and communication mechanisms. It may also include information about the applicable international law framework.⁵⁷
These matters are key for the proper functioning of the FFM, for the credibility, reliability, objectivity, and legitimacy of its process and findings, and eventually for the success of the FFM.⁵⁸ How they are dealt with depends on the FFM’s mandate, goals, and institutional basis; the wishes of the parties; and international law as the overarching regulatory tool – but what is important to stress is that fact-finding missions should have clear and transparent provisions to that effect.

# 15.3 CURRENT CHALLENGES TO FACT-FINDING AS DISPUTE SETTLEMENT MECHANISM
## 15.3.1 State Consent
The consent of the States involved in the dispute is important for the deployment of FFMs, their legitimacy, and the effective performance of their tasks. However, international organisations have often departed from this principle by relying on their competence to establish such an FFM as provided in their constitutive treaties to which States consented.⁵⁹
Such an approach is formally correct but causes two main difficulties. The first concerns the legal basis upon which the FFM can perform its tasks within the disputing States. As we saw, international organisations may recommend an FFM in which case the consent of the States involved in the dispute is critical for its deployment. However, even if an international organisation has been granted the power to establish an FFM, its deployment on the territory of a particular State, or its investigations without State consent, may amount to a violation of that State's sovereignty or an unlawful intervention.⁶⁰ Article 2(7) of the UN Charter, for example, prohibits UN intervention in the domestic jurisdiction of its member States, except for Chapter VII enforcement action. Fact-finding is not, however, enforcement action, even if it is established under Chapter VII. Even if one could say that States have granted a priori consent by becoming members of an international organisation, and even if the organisation can instruct States to accept the deployment of an FFM, if States oppose its actual deployment, the only option is to enforce the deployment of the FFM, something that may require military support.
This leads to the second difficulty which relates to the effectiveness of fact-finding. If States give their consent, the FFM will be able to access and gather information,⁶¹ which will make its work and findings more credible and reliable. In contrast, if States are forced to admit an FFM, they may obstruct its work or fail to co-operate fully. If States refuse to admit an FFM or refuse access to certain sources, an FFM may be forced to gather evidence from secondary or external sources, which may impact the reliability and credibility

# 15.3.2 Fact-Finding Structure and Methodology
As said before, having a clear and transparent structure and methodology is important, but existing practice indicates that FFMs are often deficient in this regard. For example, mandates or working methods are not always stated in clear or explicit terms.[62] Membership is often political or, at least, politicised,[63] and, more critically, the expertise or the capacity of members to handle complex facts is often questioned.
Furthermore, FFMs do not always state which standard of proof they apply when assessing evidence, and different commissions apply different standards. They include, inter alia, standards of reasonable suspicion, reasonable grounds, sufficient credible and reliable information, and sufficiently substantiated and overwhelming evidence.[64] Even if variation is to be expected given that each FFM is an independent institution having its own mandate, stating what is the applicable standard and applying it consistently is critical for the reliability and credibility of the fact-finding process and determinations, particularly if they are used for accountability purposes. ## 15.4 CYBER ATTRIBUTION AND FACT-FINDING
Following a short presentation of fact-finding, this section discusses the contours of fact-finding in the context of cyber attribution. More specifically, it considers what types of facts are pertinent for cyber attribution purposes and the methodology a cyber attribution FFM should apply to ascertain the facts. It then considers how such an FFM can be established, and, in this respect, it also assesses the proposed cyber attribution mechanisms.

All this indicates that fact-finding for cyber attribution purposes is a more holistic process. It has a strong technical component in that the facts and methods according to which facts are located, retrieved, ascertained, and assessed are primarily technical, but other non-technical facts should also be factored in.
Inevitably, this poses many challenges to fact-finding. A primary challenge is jurisdictional and refers to the ability and competence of the FFM to access evidence. Although, arguably, using cyber means and methods facilitates investigations — because it extends their reach, makes access to cyber evidence easier by not requiring physical presence, and surpasses impediments caused by geography, war, or unrest — legal jurisdictional impediments still exist. Investigations, even remote ones, require direct access to networks, and, therefore, the consent of the State or party that owns the network is needed, but access may be denied or restricted. Moreover, investigations may need to take place outside the jurisdiction of the disputing States because of the interconnected nature of cyber infrastructure and the ability of threat actors to operate from within different jurisdictions. If consent is denied, withdrawn, or restricted, fact-finding (on-site or remotely conducted) will be hindered. If the FFM carries out investigations without State consent, it may face accusations of having violated international law. If, in the absence of a direct access, it relies on external and secondary sources, the credibility, reliability, and legitimacy of its findings may be contested.
Besides jurisdictional limitations, another challenge concerns the diagnostic capacity of the FFM. For example, the FFM will need to have the appropriate technical resources, know-how, and skills in order to be able to gather and assess technical evidence. If such resources are not available or are limited, the FFM will not be able to perform these tasks efficiently or with the required degree of confidence. The immediate question is whether, in order to overcome this challenge, fact-finding can be delegated to expert third parties such as private security companies. If technical fact-finding is delegated to third parties, questions about the neutrality and impartiality of fact-finding may be raised, alongside questions about the credibility and reliability of the findings because of the inability of the FFM to scrutinise the determinations of third parties due to lack of resources, knowledge, and expertise.
This leads to another challenge, which concerns the applicable methodology. FFMs have their own rules, standards, and methods of identifying, analysing, establishing, ascertaining, probing, and using facts. The

2015 Group of Governmental Experts report stated that attribution claims should be substantiated,⁷⁹ but it did not lay down any standard. As we also said, FFMs do not apply any uniform standard, which raises questions about the applicable standard of proof. Even more critically, as indicated above, there are many difficulties in collecting and tracing cyber evidence which are compounded by the fact that an FFM cannot demand the production of evidence or use judicial or police mechanisms to obtain evidence unless this is provided in their constitutive document. What value should be placed then on secondary evidence to corroborate facts if primary evidence is hard to obtain?
In addition, the timescale within which the FFM can deliver its report is also important. Cyber fact-finding may take longer because of its complexity, the technical resources required due to the pace of developments in this area, and the jurisdictional hurdles that must be overcome. A thorough but longer investigation may increase the reliability and credibility of fact-finding, but may undermine its functions in cases where a swift action is needed. A faster fact-finding process may be more useful but less reliable. If a fact-finding mission's report is issued after action has been taken, it may reignite and escalate the dispute.

We are not going to consider the merits of each proposal, but rather categorise these proposals into those envisaging an intergovernmental cyber attribution agency and those envisaging a private cyber attribution agency and assess them accordingly.
# 15.4.2.1 Intergovernmental Cyber Attribution Agency
The creation of an intergovernmental cyber attribution agency was proposed by the Atlantic Council. More specifically, it proposed the establishment of a Multilateral Cyber Adjudication and Attribution Council (MCAAC) with mixed (public and private) membership.^[83]^
The underlying idea is that an intergovernmental cyber attribution agency grounded on State consent and operating on the basis of agreed standards and processes will overcome States’ reservations and legitimise its standing, operation, and findings. Whether an international intergovernmental attribution agency is viable at this moment in time is doubtful.
First, States treat cyber attribution as a sovereign prerogative and have repeatedly said that they have no obligation to disclose evidence.^[84]^
https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press
Fact-Finding and Cyber Attribution
Cyberspace is also a strategic domain where States pursue goals such as prevention or deterrence, or more specific political, military, or economic interests. In such an environment, the role of a permanent international FFM is quite peripheral in States' thinking because it may restrict their freedom to attribute when they want and for the reasons they want.⁸⁵ For example, in a situation of inter-State conflict or tensions, a State may decide not to attribute, even if it possesses the relevant facts, in order not to aggravate the situation, avoid domestic pressure to take action, or not to attract retaliation. In contrast, a State may decide to attribute, even if it does not hold all the facts, if important interests are endangered and the State has decided to act. As Nicolas Politis has observed, fact-finding was envisaged for disputes where the essential interests of a State were not at stake.⁸⁶
Second, States have asymmetric cyber capabilities, with certain States having very sophisticated and robust attribution technologies and mechanisms. Consequently, the benefits of an agency performing attribution on their behalf are negligible, and there are no benefits in sharing their attribution technology with such an agency which will then antagonise them.
Third, the findings of such an agency, but also any legal conclusions that can be inferred, may be contested due to the absence of a firm legal framework regarding the scope and content of States' international law obligations in cyberspace, or due to the controversies surrounding the attribution criteria in the law of State responsibility. For example, what constitutes a cyber armed attack, whether sovereignty is a rule that applies to cyberspace, and whether 'overall control' is an attribution criterion are subject to debate. As a result, such controversies will lead to further controversies about the type and calibre of evidence and the applicable standard of proof.
on the attributing State to disclose that basis. However, a State may choose as a matter of policy to disclose specific information that it considered in making its attribution decision, and may be required to defend any such decision as part of international legal proceedings'; Switzerland, 'Switzerland's position paper on the application of international law in cyberspace, Annex UN GGE 2019/2021', www.eda.admin.ch/content/dam/eda/en/documents/aussenpolitik/voelkerrecht/20210527-Schweiz-Annex-UN-GGE-Cybersecurity-2019-2021_EN.pdf (accessed 14 July 2022), p. 6: 'The decision to attribute conduct is at the discretion of the injured State and there is no obligation under international law to disclose the information leading to such a decision.'
⁸⁵ The UK, for example, will 'attribute specific cyber identities publicly', when it is judged 'in the national interest to do so'. HM Government, 'National Cyber Security Strategy 2016–2021', UK Government, 2016, https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/567242/national_cyber_security_strategy_2016.pdf (accessed 14 July 2022), p. 50 at s. 6.3.3.
⁸⁶ Nicolas Politis, 'Les commissions internationales d'enquête' (1912) 19 RGDIP 149–88 at 153.
https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press
Fourth, such an agency is compared to existing international mechanisms performing inspection and verification functions, such as those under the IAEA or OPCW. However, there is a critical difference between them and the proposed agency. Whereas the IAEA and OPCW have established a comprehensive regulatory regime where inspections are integral to securing compliance with States' obligations, no such regime exists for cyberspace to which fact-finding can be attached.
All these issues make the creation of an intergovernmental cyber attribution agency quite unlikely, at least in the foreseeable future. However, even if such an attribution agency is eventually created, it will still confront several challenges.
Its membership will most likely be limited due to States' diverse cyber capabilities and the rivalry that currently characterises their relations. Technologically developed States or cyber powers, in general, may chose to remain outside such an agency because of the limited benefits they will receive. This immediately raises questions about the agency's resources and its mandate. If the agency's resources are inadequate, will its mandate be limited and, in this case, what will be its added value? If important cyber powers are not members, will its findings be reliable and credible? Also, what will be its leverage to conduct investigations into third States, or States that have isolated their cyberspace? If technologically developed States do participate, would that create an imbalance and invite accusations of bias regarding its findings? If a State is frequently accused of cyberattacks, is there any benefit in participating in such an agency?
An intergovernmental cyber attribution agency will also face certain methodological challenges, such as regarding the criteria according to which attribution incidents will be investigated and the type of attribution it will perform, for example, technical and/or legal. These issues need to be determined in advance, but it is doubtful whether that will be possible due to the permanent and general competence of such an agency, the dynamic nature of cyber incidents, the difficulty in disentangling law from facts, and the inherent power of institutions to interpret and determine their mandate in view of new circumstances.
Another critical question is who will conduct the fact-finding. If fact-finding is to be performed by State officials, the process may be politicised. If it is to be performed by the agency's staff, recruited because of their qualifications and professional experience, the agency will need to build its own fact-finding
capabilities and expertise, but the immediate question is who is going to provide the resources, know-how, and training. As we said, States may be reluctant to share their technical attribution tools and knowledge, and, in general, they may not be ready to support and fund the development of attribution expertise by such an agency which can then compete with them. If investigations or capacity-building is delegated to third parties, such as the private sector, instead, it may affect the legitimacy, impartiality, and reliability of an agency, as mentioned previously.
Other methodological challenges include the applicable standard of proof; the legal framework governing the agency's investigations such as human rights law or intellectual property law; the availability of review mechanisms; and the manner in which and to whom findings will be communicated, for example, whether they will be made public or remain confidential.
How an agency will make decisions presents another challenge. Consensus-based decisions may be more acceptable, but trying to build consensus may impact the ability of the agency to make quick decisions, or may affect the quality and transparency of its decisions. If decisions are majority-based, division and accusations may follow.
Ensuring the accountability of such an agency is another challenge. Its findings may be relied upon by States to act, which raises the question of whether the agency can be held responsible for incorrect determinations, or for assisting in the commission of unlawful acts. If a State, for instance, relies on the agency's findings to take countermeasures against another State which contends that the countermeasures were unlawful because the attribution was mistaken, can the agency be held responsible for incorrect findings, or for aiding in the commission of wrongful acts? If the matter is brought before a court or an arbitration tribunal, what value should be placed on the findings of such an agency? For example, should that court or tribunal treat them as mitigating circumstances when considering damages?
There is also the fundamental question of the status of the agency. If it is consultative, its contribution to dispute settlement may be negligible because States may employ other mechanisms or use their own judgment to settle their cyber attribution disputes. However, even in this case, there is still a danger of aggravating an existing dispute because its findings, even if non-binding, may be used by States to validate or disprove attribution claims, thus providing no closure to the dispute. If its status is adjudicatory and its findings are binding
Nicholas Tsagourias and Fiona Middleton
on States, this would require transparent working methods but also accountability, which pose their own challenges, as mentioned above.
## 15.4.2.2 A Private Cyber Attribution Agency
A proposal for the creation of a private cyber attribution agency was put forward by RAND. More specifically, it proposed the creation of a Global Cyber Attribution Consortium whose role would be to attribute major cyberattacks with a high degree of confidence and release the evidence and its findings to the public.⁸⁹
According to the proposal, the agency's membership will be multi-stakeholder, consisting of technical, legal, and policy experts from academia, research organisations, and cybersecurity and information technology companies, but State representatives will be excluded. The agency will also follow a standardised methodology regarding the collection of evidence, assessment, standard of proof, review, notification, and publication of findings.
It is claimed that the private character of such an agency will remove suspicions of politicisation, and its findings will contribute to dispute settlement by making attribution neutral, credible, and reliable. According to RAND, the consortium can only derive its legitimacy over time from 'the reputation and credibility gained from the technical expertise of its diverse global membership and its commitment to objectivity and transparency in its attribution findings'.⁹⁰
Although the proposal tries to circumvent State reluctance or suspicion towards an intergovernmental attribution agency, it is reasonable to ask whether it is appropriate and viable to exclude States to the extent that attribution determinations, even if they are exclusively factual, may affect State interests and decisions or have legal consequences, for example, the imposition of sanctions.⁹¹ Questions may also be asked about the competence and ability of such an agency to conduct investigations when States involved
⁸⁹ Davis et al., *Stateless Attribution*. Microsoft has also put forward various proposals, but their nature is not clear. It first proposed a non-governmental organisation made up of experts. See Microsoft, 'An attribution organization to strengthen trust online', https://query.prod.cms.rt.microsoft.com/cms/api/am/binary/RW67QI (accessed 14 July 2022). Later it proposed an international organisation with public-private membership to investigate technically nation State attacks resembling the IAEA. Scott Charney et al., 'From articulation to implementation: Enabling progress on cybersecurity norms', *Microsoft*, June 2016, https://query.prod.cms.rt.microsoft.com/cms/api/am/binary/REVmc8 (accessed 14 July 2022).
⁹⁰ Davis et al., *Stateless Attribution*, p. 30.
⁹¹ Council of the European Union, 'Council Decision (CFSP) 2020/1127 of 30 July 2020 amending Decision (CFSP) 2019/797 concerning restrictive measures against cyber-attacks threatening the Union or its Member States' 2020 OJ (L246) 12.
https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press
in a dispute refuse to co-operate. The private character of such an agency does not ensure that States will co-operate or disclose information. Furthermore, depending on how information is gathered, handled, assessed, and communicated by such an agency, the credibility and reliability of its findings can be challenged for lack of evidence or faulty methodology.
There are several other challenges facing a private attribution agency. First, whereas the participation of private security companies can boost the technical capabilities of the agency, how they will be selected is critical for the credibility of the agency. Secondly, these companies will continue to operate independently and often compete with the agency, which will raise questions about their commitment to the work of the agency. Third, in a competitive cybersecurity market, other private cybersecurity companies may challenge the agency's findings, which can create confusion and lower the level of confidence in the agency. Fourth, the private sector is not equally developed in all States, and States have different views about its role in cyber governance, which may create suspicion or even opposition to the involvement of the private sector.
Another challenge concerns the accountability of this agency for the same reasons mentioned above, but with an additional twist. If the agency does not operate under international law, it will not be subject to international law's accountability mechanisms. This immediately raises the question of whether national accountability mechanisms will be used against the agency or its individual members. If that is to happen, it will have a chilling effect on the agency and create confusion and uncertainty.
Finally, the private character of such an agency may pose a systemic challenge to international law because it will antagonise or even undermine States which, as we said, want to preserve their power to perform attribution and settle their disputes as they see fit. Such an agency may also undermine States' control over the international law process of rule creation, application, and interpretation if it is involved, explicitly or implicitly, in the interpretation or application of international law or in laying down new standards. In addition, another systemic challenge should be mentioned. The proliferation of attribution mechanisms may cause more confusion and conflict and aggravate disputes further instead of settling them.
All this means that such an agency's claim to neutrality, reliability, and legality may not be fully supported.
## 15.5 Moving forward: an ffm for cyber attribution?
In the preceding sections, we identified several institutional, structural, and methodological challenges that affect cyber attribution fact-finding. That said,
Nicholas Tsagourias and Fiona Middleton
cyber attribution disputes exist and, if not settled, may aggravate or exacerbate the underlying political and legal disputes. Thus, the question of how to establish the facts underlying a cyber attribution claim cannot go away. For this reason, in this section we will present the key features and attributes of a cyber attribution FFM which, in our opinion, could address many of the aforementioned challenges.
In the first place, such an FFM should be created by States voluntarily and on an ad hoc basis in relation to a particular cyber attribution dispute.92 States' involvement in its creation and design will demonstrate their determination to settle the attribution dispute. It will also elicit their cooperation and compliance since the FFM will be entangled with the particular interests and expectations of the disputing States. Finally, it will contribute to the credibility, legitimacy, and effectiveness of the FFM. This does not contradict what we said previously, namely that States view cyber attribution as their sovereign prerogative and claim that they have no obligation to disclose evidence, or that they use attribution for strategic purposes. These remain true, but they are more pertinent in relation to fact-finding performed by permanent international institutions over which disputing States have little control, or in relation to demands to publicly disclose information. However, if States determine that settling a cyber attribution dispute is more important than letting the dispute linger or aggravate, and that settling it through an FFM is appropriate, effective, and serves their interests, they may go ahead to create such an FFM and co-operate with it. As a matter of fact, this is not against their sovereignty but confirmation of their sovereignty.
From a broader perspective, this approach to FFMs accords with the fact that States are the primary creators and designers of dispute settlement mechanisms, and that fact-finding was originally envisaged as a bilateral mechanism of dispute settlement and not as an institutional one.
Since being created by States, the FFM should be treaty-based. States will thus be able to specify in its constitutive instrument its composition, mandate, and methodology.
The composition of the FFM should be determined by the States concerned, depending on the nature and mandate of the FFM. Members can be State officials, staff borrowed from international organisations, individuals drawn from the private sector, or NGOs. Their expertise can also cover different fields, for example, technology and/or law. We are thus not prescriptive as existing proposals are, and we do not place value on a certain type of membership, but believe that membership should reflect the interests and needs of the States which establish the FFM.
92 UNGA, 'Declaration on fact-finding', paras 6 and 21.
https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press
Fact-Finding and Cyber Attribution
Insofar as its mandate is concerned, it should again be determined by States. In the first place, the constitutive instrument should specify the subject matter of the investigation. It should specify, for example, which incident(s) will be investigated and under what circumstances other related incidents will be investigated. It should also specify what type of facts it will gather and assess, and whether the FFM will perform only technical and/or legal attribution. This is important because it has implications for the methodology the FFM will follow. In addition to the above, the FFM's constitutive instrument should specify the location of the investigations, for example, which and whose networks it will investigate, and under what circumstances it will extend its investigations to connected networks. It should also specify the timeframe of investigations; the processes and conditions of gathering, storing, handling, or sharing evidence; the process according to which evidence will be assessed; and the means of establishing their authenticity and reliability.
Furthermore, the constitutive instrument should specify the applicable standard of proof depending on the type of attribution it will perform, and whether the FFM will have an adjudicatory or consultative function. It should also state how and by whom its findings will be reviewed.
There are several other issues that the FFM's constitutive instrument should specify. It should specify the terms and words used in the mandate, such as attribution, networks, and non-State actors. It should specify the guiding principles of the FFM, for example, its adherence to the principles of transparency, fairness, neutrality, and accountability. It should specify the law that will apply to the FFM and its investigations, for example, whether the investigations will be conducted according to international law.
Regarding the decision-making process, the constitutive instrument should state whether decisions will be consensual or majority-based. It should also explain the reporting and communication process, including whether the findings will remain private and confidential, or made public, and whether, in the latter case, evidence will be made public. This is important because it will have implications on the applicable methodology.
The constitutive instrument should make provisions for a continuous supply of financial,[93] technical, or any other resources required for the performance of the FFM's duties.
https://doi.org/10.1017/9781009076296.023 Published online by Cambridge University Press
Finally, the constitutive instrument should establish internal and/or external accountability mechanisms.
We believe that, if States create a cyber attribution FFM which addresses all these issues with the requisite care, the FFM will be able to operate smoothly and efficiently and establish the facts underpinning cyber attribution disputes in a credible and reliable manner. It can thus contribute to dispute resolution without becoming itself the subject of a dispute.
### 15.6 conclusion
This chapter has considered the role of fact-finding as a mechanism for settling cyber attribution disputes. In this respect, it discussed its merits but also identified several challenges it is facing relating to its legal basis, institutional nature, structure, and methodology. The chapter then went on to present certain key features a cyber attribution FFM should exhibit, which will enable it, in the view of the authors, to perform its fact-finding tasks effectively. In our opinion, if fact-finding is calibrated appropriately, it can contribute to the peaceful settlement of cyber attribution disputes.

## NICHOLAS TSAGOURIAS AND FIONA MIDDLETON
### 15.1 INTRODUCTION
As our societies become increasingly reliant on cyberspace, they also become vulnerable to cyberattacks committed by States or non-State actors either independently or in collaboration with each other. States and non-State actors exploit this complex environment and the anonymity, speed, and interconnectivity it affords to cause harm. Attribution is important in such a context because it concerns the process of assigning a cyberattack to its source, which is a prerequisite for any remedial action and for establishing responsibility.
In international law, attribution refers to the legal process of assigning an act or omission to a State (or another subject of international law), and it is one of the constitutive elements of the law of State responsibility. A State can incur responsibility only if a wrongful act or omission is attributed to it according to the criteria established in the law of State responsibility. A cyberattack can thus be attributed to a State according to the criteria contained in Articles 4–11 of the International Law Commission’s Draft Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (2001) and engage its responsibility if it constitutes a breach of one of its obligations.
That said, attribution, in general, and cyber attribution, in particular, have also a factual dimension. The factual dimension of cyber attribution refers to the attribution of a cyberattack to its source based on technical facts. This requires technical investigations conducted mainly by cyber forensics experts.
 The term ‘cyberattack’ is used here generically to refer to malicious cyber operations.

The two processes of attribution (legal and factual/technical) cannot be clearly decoupled because legal attribution is fact-dependent. To explain, facts need to be discovered and assessed according to the legal criteria of attribution in order to assign a particular cyberattack to a State for legal purposes.
It is for this reason that attribution claims are often accompanied by reports containing supporting evidence. These reports are compiled by the State making the attribution claim, often assisted by private cybersecurity companies. However, in most cases these reports are quite thin on evidence and do not always explain how facts were assessed. Consequently, accused States, and sometimes third States, contest the attribution claims by disputing the facts and the supporting evidence.

# 15.2 FACT-FINDING AND INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE SETTLEMENT
Fact-finding as a method of dispute settlement has been recognised in the 1899 Hague Convention for the Pacific Settlement of International Disputes and is also mentioned in Article 33 of the UN Charter.[21] Its importance for the peaceful settlement of disputes and for maintaining international peace was also stressed by the UN General Assembly (UNGA) in several Resolutions.[22]
The primary aim of fact-finding is to 'elucidate' facts underlying a dispute by locating, identifying, verifying, corroborating, and analysing them.[23] The assumption is that by resolving factual controversies, it is not only the factual

dispute that will be settled, but also that legal disputes linked to the facts will be prevented, accommodated, or settled.
Although fact-finding was envisaged as an objective and impartial mechanism of ascertaining facts, it evolved over the years to address a range of different situations and issues. For example, fact-finding missions have been endowed with monitoring, alerting, and recommendatory tasks. They have also exercised adjudicative functions by identifying violations of international law or determining the applicability of specific legal rules, and in this way, fact-finding contributed directly or indirectly to accountability at the individual or State level. This meant that the nature of fact-finding changed from investigating facts to acquiring a juridical dimension either directly or indirectly because facts cannot be disentangled easily from law. As a result of such changes, fact-finding has sometimes exacerbated existing disputes or triggered additional disputes about fact-finding itself.

## 15.2.2 Fact-Finding Structure and Methodology
A FFM’s structure and methodology includes, among others, matters concerning membership, mandates, resources, and working methods; the time-scale and territorial scope of the investigations; the type of evidence that will be used and how it will be gathered, handled, and assessed; the applicable standard of proof; and reporting and communication mechanisms. It may also include information about the applicable international law framework.
These matters are key for the proper functioning of the FFM, for the credibility, reliability, objectivity, and legitimacy of its process and findings, and eventually for the success of the FFM. How they are dealt with depends on the FFM’s mandate, goals, and institutional basis; the wishes of the parties; and international law as the overarching regulatory tool – but what is important to stress is that fact-finding missions should have clear and transparent provisions to that effect.

# 15.3 CURRENT CHALLENGES TO FACT-FINDING AS DISPUTE SETTLEMENT MECHANISM
## 15.3.1 State Consent
The consent of the States involved in the dispute is important for the deployment of FFMs, their legitimacy, and the effective performance of their tasks. However, international organisations have often departed from this principle by relying on their competence to establish such an FFM as provided in their constitutive treaties to which States consented.
Such an approach is formally correct but causes two main difficulties. The first concerns the legal basis upon which the FFM can perform its tasks within the disputing States. As we saw, international organisations may recommend an FFM in which case the consent of the States involved in the dispute is critical for its deployment. However, even if an international organisation has been granted the power to establish an FFM, its deployment on the territory of a particular State, or its investigations without State consent, may amount to a violation of that State's sovereignty or an unlawful intervention. Article 2(7) of the UN Charter, for example, prohibits UN intervention in the domestic jurisdiction of its member States, except for Chapter VII enforcement action. Fact-finding is not, however, enforcement action, even if it is established under Chapter VII. Even if one could say that States have granted a priori consent by becoming members of an international organisation, and even if the organisation can instruct States to accept the deployment of an FFM, if States oppose its actual deployment, the only option is to enforce the deployment of the FFM, something that may require military support.
This leads to the second difficulty which relates to the effectiveness of fact-finding. If States give their consent, the FFM will be able to access and gather information, which will make its work and findings more credible and reliable. In contrast, if States are forced to admit an FFM, they may obstruct its work or fail to co-operate fully. If States refuse to admit an FFM or refuse access to certain sources, an FFM may be forced to gather evidence from secondary or external sources, which may impact the reliability and credibility

# 15.3.2 Fact-Finding Structure and Methodology
As said before, having a clear and transparent structure and methodology is important, but existing practice indicates that FFMs are often deficient in this regard. For example, mandates or working methods are not always stated in clear or explicit terms.[62] Membership is often political or, at least, politicised,[63] and, more critically, the expertise or the capacity of members to handle complex facts is often questioned.
Furthermore, FFMs do not always state which standard of proof they apply when assessing evidence, and different commissions apply different standards. They include, inter alia, standards of reasonable suspicion, reasonable grounds, sufficient credible and reliable information, and sufficiently substantiated and overwhelming evidence.[64] Even if variation is to be expected given that each FFM is an independent institution having its own mandate, stating what is the applicable standard and applying it consistently is critical for the reliability and credibility of the fact-finding process and determinations, particularly if they are used for accountability purposes. Otherwise determinations may be contested or used arbitrarily by one of the parties to reaffirm its own version of facts.

Technical evidence consists of artefacts drawn from the tools, techniques, and procedures used for the cyberattack. It includes, among others, command-and-control servers, IP addresses, websites, activity logs, time stamps, malware and their design, names, and pseudonyms, software programmes, e-mails, instructions, language strings, documents, and so on. Technical evidence can be collected through technical investigations from different points of the cyberattack cycle: preparation, reconnaissance, exploitation, execution, and post-execution phase.
